biography:
‚ñ´Ô∏èTravel & Architectural Photographer üì∑
‚ñ´Ô∏èDrone Operator üöÅ
From Milan üáÆüáπ
I travel the world to capture its beautyüó∫Ô∏è
‚ú® @siruiimaging Ambassador
.

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
One of the most beautiful things about landmarks is that even if they are incredibly famous, each one of us has his/her own memory, an intimate interpretation of what's seen by millions. ‚ú®
5 years ago I was starting to work as a product designer (that's what I graduated in), but I wasn't really certain about it. That's because deep within myself I knew what I really wanted to do, but I was scared to acknowledge that.ü§ê
Somehow I started posting pictures here on Instagram, and as I wanted to create new content, I visited Paris with my mother & sisters.
I just had a tiny camera with 2 lenses, but I really loved exploring the city and experimenting with my new gear.ü§ì
Among all the places I saw, there was one that really got me: Notre-Dame.üïç
I visited its incredible interiors, went up to its balcony (even if back then I was pretty much afraid of heights), and on the last day, I decided to wake up really early to take a picture with no tourists.
.
That was the first time I woke up before sunrise for taking a photograph.
That was one of the first moments when I realized what I truly wanted to be in my life: a photographer.üì∑
I was so proud of that picture back then [you can see it as a 2nd picture in this post], while I smile when I look at it now. 
I still had so much to learn.
.
I went back to Paris 2 years later, and I couldn't miss the morning meeting with my past muse so I again woke up early, and I shot the very first lights of day on a pretty cold and windy morning.
It was as beautiful as 2 years earlier.
.
I somehow thought this would become a "classic appointment" in my life, a morning meeting every few years with Notre-Dame, in the silence of the dawn, just with the sound of the wind and of the river Seine.
Now though, a vast portion of that majestic beauty has turned to ashes.
It's inexplicable, unbelievable, but sadly true.
.
I am grateful for having had the chance to see you, and portray your unique beauty at the best that I could.
Dear Notre-Dame, your original grace will be deeply missed.üôèüèª
posts.accessibility_caption: Image may contain: sky, outdoor, water and nature

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Majestic architecture in Berlin, Germany üá©üá™‚ú® [read below the thought behind the shot]‚¨áÔ∏è
__________________________________________
Architectural Photography is not just "taking pictures of architecture". Actually, it's all about understanding the essence of the project and translating that on a 2-dimensional plane, a photograph. üì∑
Architects spend years designing, planning, and executing projects of this kind, and we as viewers should stop more often to admire in awe of their work. üòÆ
Here's my suggestion for you: next time you see a beautiful building in your city, try to stop for a second and wonder "Why is it like this?" and "What did the architect want to communicate with this?".
This will help you open up your mind to a new way of interpretation of what you see.ü§©
#Archilover .
üëèThe architect of this majestic work of art: @stephanbraunfels
üì∑Camera: @sonyalpha a7RII
üî≠Tripod: @siruiimaging N-2204SK

When the old meets the new - K√∂ln, Germany üá©üá™‚ú® [read below the full story behind the shot]
__________________________________________
As an #archilover I always find it interesting when new architectures are built close to historical ones. In this picture you can see the K√∂lner Dom, a medieval church built in the 1200, and the three Kranhaus, built in the early 2000s.
‚û°Ô∏è Which one do you prefer?‚ùì
__________________________________________
Fun fact about this shot: I was shooting from a bridge used by trains to cross the river, and it took countless takes in order to get a sharp long exposure, as trains were passing pretty frequently. This is the only good shot, as all the others I took during a full hour shooting are blurred ü§ì
Camera: @sonyalpha a7RII
Tripod: @siruiimaging N-2204SK

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Archi Love in K√∂ln üá©üá™‚ú®
#takenwithHuawei
[read below the full story behind the shot]
__________________________________________
I had just been back from the US üá∫üá≤ I was facing a pretty huge jet-lag and I didn't have time to get over it, as I had a very tight schedule in K√∂ln. üíº
Tired and sleepy, after a very long day, I still wanted to photograph this amazing architectural complex, which was just a 10-min walk from my apartment.
Once arrived to the shooting location I thought that this would have been the perfect opportunity to test my #huaweip20pro Night Mode üåÜ as I just needed to activate the mode and press the shutter button, something doable even if this tired.
I gave it a try and "oh boy!üòÆ", I have been really amazed by the results, as it captured and incredible amount of light over a few seconds, giving me a pretty clean & detailed picture, all without needing a tripod! ü§Ø
‚Ü©Ô∏è
Back in university I graduated in design (industrial design to be specific), and that really opened my mind in terms of understanding that behind each object, even the most simple one, there's so, so much work. 
Some might think that design is that frivolous thing that "makes things beautiful", but it's quite the opposite. To design, is to create something that works, that makes life easier to someone, just as making a jet-lagged traveler take night shots with its phone.
Beauty lies within the essence of the function itself.
Awesome work @huaweimobileit ü§ì
[Here's a slice of üçï for you that read the whole caption, I appreciate your time!]
posts.accessibility_caption: Image may contain: sky and outdoor

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Every January is like being presented with a blank canvas: it's all up to us what will get painted on it. üé®
I wish you all to live a meaningful 2019, where you will go for your dream even if it seems far, lost somewhere behind the horizon. üåÖ
__________________________________________
[Looking back at 2018]
It has been a year of transition, learning, and growth.
I've taken my longest trip yet, living 104 days around South East Asia üåè without a fixed base an experience which I'm looking forward to repeating in the future, and that I recommend you do somewhere along your path. ‚ú®
Living out of a suitcaseüíº, without the "daily comforts" that we all give for granted (just like making espresso‚òï whenever I want one), was an incredibly valuable life lesson. üôè
It taught me that I don't really need all the material things that I have, that we as humans have an incredible capacity to adapt, and that we are biased by our own culture more than we might think of.
After all, it taught me that the true essence of traveling is to embrace whatever we encounter like a child would, with no judgment whatsoever, bearing nothing more than curiosity and the desire to learn üåü

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Peace at Cefal√π Bay üòç
Shot for #ClubMed with #DJI #Mavic2Pro.
[Read below the full story behind the shot].
__________________________________________
That day the afternoon had been pretty cloudy and flat‚òÅÔ∏è, so I had no plans to shoot the sunset. On the contrary, I had a meeting going on. 
All of a sudden though, the sun made its appearance and started creating beautiful colors all around the scene.üé®
To continue the meeting or to shoot the sunset? That is the question.ü§î
.
Of course, I had no doubt on what to do: I fled the meeting, ran to my room to pick up my @djiglobal drone, and I took off right outside my door. üò¨
The sun was going on fast, but I made it just in time to capture this beautiful scene at @clubmed @ClubMedCefalu!ü§©
.
Photography is a lot about planning, but sometimes you gotta improvise (and run)üèÉüí®
posts.accessibility_caption: Image may contain: 1 person, sky, cloud, ocean, outdoor, nature and water

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Swim in a heated pool, relax in a cozy villa, or swim in the cold sea? üòç
Shot for #ClubMed with #DJI #MavicAir.
[Read below the full story behind the shot].
__________________________________________
If you want to know my answer to the above question, I haven't done any of those activities as I was just too busy shooting this stunning property, @ClubMedCefalu by @ClubMed üòÅ
.
That's ok though, as there's nothing better than doing what you love. That puts you in a state defined as "flow": you just live in the present moment, focusing all of yourself in what you are doing. ‚ú®
That definitely happens everytime I'm behind the camera or when flying @djiglobal drones.
.
I wish everyone to find "their thing" and go for it, as there's no better feeling üôè

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Sicilian Summer in November üåÖ
Shot while flying from #ClubMed with #DJI #MavicAir üëá[Read below the full story behind this shot]üëá
__________________________________________
Just as I've started the caption of my previous post, I can't believe it took me this long for traveling to one of the most beautiful regions in the world, Sicily, which is just a 1-hour flight from where I live üáÆüáπ
.
It has been an intense 10-day trip, shooting a truly stunning property by @ClubMed: @ClubMedCefalu.
Being built on rugged cliffs with a breathtaking view over Cefal√π Bay, I focused on shooting aerials images of the property (see more of it in the upcoming posts) with @djiglobal drones. üöÅ
The view of Cefal√π you see from this photograph is the one you get from the resort, a view that left me in awe every morning, every afternoon, and every evening. ü§©
.
It's hard to define with words what Sicily is, so I'll leave you with a quote by the great J. W. von Goethe: "Italy without Sicily leaves no image on the soul here is the key to all." ‚ú®
posts.accessibility_caption: Image may contain: ocean, sky, outdoor, nature and water

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Florence üáÆüáπ
[read below the full story behind these shots]
__________________________________________
I can't believe it took me this long for traveling to one of the most beautiful cities in the world, which happens to be just 2h of train from where I live. In fact, we so often take for granted the beautiful things close to us, that we forget about them.
.
I've recently had the opportunity to visit Florence for a very special reason: a conference where I have been announced as a @siruiimaging ambassador! ü§©
I am using their tripods for my travel photography since the beginning, and I couldn't be happier for this recognition, for which I express my gratitude to the whole team. üôèüèª
.
During the event (see the pictures in the carousel), I've had the chance to give a speech about my journey in the "photography world", including the struggle for wanting to make a career out of what most people refer to as a hobby. I've loved doing it with the intent of serving others, making them want to explore the world more üó∫Ô∏è and to go for their dreams no matter what.‚ú®
posts.accessibility_caption: Image may contain: sky, cloud and outdoor

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Amusement Park on the Santa Monica Pier üá∫üá≤‚ú®
[read below the full story behind this shot]
_____________________________________
My stay in LA was pretty short, and I could just 3 sunsets. The Santa Monica Pier is such an iconic location that definitely deserved its own shootingüé¢
.
I arrived, positioned my tripod between the sand and the water, and waited.
As soon as the sun went down, the sky got illuminated by this gorgeous warm light, a gentle breeze was touching the sea everything was perfect.ü§©
.
So perfect that a young couple went with their feet inside the water, and started to hug  during the best moment, just in the middle of my frame üòÖ
I wanted to go there and kindly ask them to move just a bit (I don't think they had noticed me), but I decided that their special moment was more important than my picture.
.
That was a REALLY long hug, something like 10-15min, and when they went away the sky wasn't that nice anymore.
Gladly, with some Photoshop magic, I was able to "kindly remove them" from my shot.
At the end of the day, we all got what we wanted: I got my shot, and they got their beautiful memory üôÇ

posts.edge_media_to_caption:
Light trails at the iconic "Venice Sign" in Los Angeles üá∫üá≤‚ú®
‚¨áÔ∏è[read below the full story behind the shot]‚¨áÔ∏è
__________________________________________
As a professional photographer I normally shoot with big cameras, but as a technology lover I sometimes wonder if it would be possible to shoot a light trail picture with a phone.ü§î
Just a day before leaving for my trip to LA, @huaweimobileit sent over their #huaweip20pro to let me test the capabilities of its camera.
I also happen to love challenges, so the game was on.üí™
I had just spent the evening around Abbot Kinney Boulevard with the one and only @lantonova üç∏, and now it was time to get to work.
I positioned my tripod just below the sidewalk, and I started shooting with the phone, using its manual mode and RAW files (40 megapixels eachüò±).
I didn't know what to expect, as it was the first time I was using the camera of the phone in such conditions.
So once at home I imported the picture on my computer, and I was blown away (or should I say  Huawei). ü§©
#takenwithHuawei

Last rays of sun in Los Angeles üá∫üá≤‚ú® [read below for the full story behind the shot]
__________________________________________
I planned shooting this classical view of the City of Angels since quite some time. Unfortunately, when I arrived at the location I found out that the viewpoint would have closed before sunset. üòØ
As I am a "blue hour" kind of guy, I was pretty upset about this, as well as the guys next to me. In fact, just beside me, there was a @bbc crew which was there filming some B-roll for a documentary.üé•
We didn't capture the blue hour, but we somehow managed to stay well over the closing time and get the last rays of the sun, which as you can see from the picture create a beautiful effect.
All this was possible thanks to a super cool LAPD officer, which was there on duty and allowed us to stay 40-min longer. üôè
His act of kindness & understanding allowed the crew to get their job done, and me to shoot at a time of day where I normally don't, letting me go out of my "photography comfort zone".
Thank you buddy ü§úüèª‚ú®ü§õüèø
#smallthings
